content:
Please execute the following task in my repository mcpmark-eval-zl/claude-code:

I need you to implement a comprehensive label documentation and organization workflow for the repository.

**Step 1: Create Label Documentation Issue**
Create a new issue with:
- Title containing: "Document label organization for better visual organization" and "label guide"
- Body must include:
  - A "## Problem" heading describing the need for better label documentation
  - A "## Proposed Solution" heading about creating a comprehensive label guide for different label categories
  - A "## Benefits" heading listing improved visual organization and easier issue triage
  - Keywords: "label documentation", "visual organization", "label guide", "organization"
- Labels: Initially add "enhancement" and "documentation" labels to the issue

**Step 2: Create Feature Branch**
Create a new branch called 'feat/label-color-guide' from main.

**Step 3: Create Label Documentation**
On the feature branch, create the file `docs/LABEL_COLORS.md` with:
- A "# Label Organization Guide" title
- A "## Label Categories" section with a table that MUST follow this exact format:
```markdown
| Label Name | Category | Description |
|------------|----------|-------------|
```
The table must include ALL existing labels in the repository. For each label:
- Group labels by category (e.g., issue-type, platform, area, status, performance)
- Include a description for each label

- A "## Usage Guidelines" section explaining when to use each label category

**Step 4: Apply ALL Labels to the Documentation Issue**
Update the issue you created in Step 1 by adding ALL existing labels from the repository. This serves as a visual demonstration of the label organization. The issue should have every single label that exists in the repository applied to it.

**Step 5: Create Pull Request**
Create a pull request from 'feat/label-color-guide' to 'main' with:
- Title containing: "Add label organization guide" and "visual organization"  
- Body must include:
  - A "## Summary" heading explaining the label organization documentation
  - A "## Changes" heading with a bullet list of what was added
  - "Fixes #[ISSUE_NUMBER]" pattern linking to your created issue
  - A "## Verification" section stating that all labels have been documented
  - Keywords: "label documentation", "organization guide", "visual improvement", "documentation"
- Labels: Add a reasonable subset of labels to the PR (at least 5-10 labels from different categories)

**Step 6: Document Changes in Issue**
Add a comment to the original issue with:
- Confirmation that the label documentation has been created
- Total count of labels documented
- Reference to the PR using "PR #[NUMBER]" pattern
- Keywords: "documentation created", "label guide complete", "organization complete"

Note: Based on your understanding, solve the task all at once by yourself, don't ask for my opinions on anything.

This leads to inconsistent label application and makes issue triage less efficient.\\n\\n## Proposed Solution\\n\\nCreate a comprehensive label guide that documents all existing labels in the repository, organizing them by categories such as issue-type, platform, area, status, and performance. This documentation will include descriptions for each label and usage guidelines for different label categories.\\n\\n## Benefits\\n\\n- Improved visual organization of issues and pull requests\\n- Easier issue triage and categorization\\n- Consistent label usage across the project\\n- Better onboarding experience for new contributors\\n- Enhanced project maintainability and organization\\n\\nKeywords: label documentation, visual organization, label guide, organization\", \"labels\": [\"enhancement\", \"documentation\"]}", "include_output_fields": ["number", "html_url", "title"]}

content.text:
Perfect! I have successfully implemented the comprehensive label documentation and organization workflow for your repository. Here's a summary of what was completed:

## Task Completed Successfully! ✅

### **Step 1: Create Label Documentation Issue ✅**
- Created issue #54: "Document label organization for better visual organization - label guide"
- Included all required sections (Problem, Proposed Solution, Benefits)
- Initially labeled with "enhancement" and "documentation"

### **Step 2: Create Feature Branch ✅**
- Created branch `feat/label-color-guide` from main branch
- Branch is ready for development work

### **Step 3: Create Label Documentation ✅**
- Created `docs/LABEL_COLORS.md` file on the feature branch
- Documented all 26 existing repository labels in a structured table format
- Organized labels by categories:
  - **Issue-type** (4 labels): bug, enhancement, documentation, question
  - **Area** (10 labels): api, auth, core, ide, mcp, model, packaging, security, tools, tui
  - **Platform** (3 labels): linux, macos, windows
  - **Performance** (2 labels): perf:memory, memory
  - **Status** (4 labels): duplicate, invalid, wontfix, has repro
  - **Priority** (2 labels): help wanted, good first issue
  - **Source** (1 label): external
- Added comprehensive usage guidelines for each label category

### **Step 4: Apply ALL Labels to Documentation Issue ✅**
- Applied all 26 existing repository labels to issue #54
- This serves as a visual demonstration of the label organization system

### **Step 5: Create Pull Request ✅**
- Created PR #55: "Add label organization guide - visual organization"
- Included proper sections (Summary, Changes, Verification) with "Fixes #54" reference
- Applied 10 relevant labels from different categories to the PR

### **Step 6: Document Changes in Issue ✅**
- Added comprehensive comment to issue #54 documenting completion
- Confirmed total count of 26 labels documented
- Referenced PR #55 and included all required keywords

The workflow is now complete with:
- **Issue #54**: https://github.com/mcpmark-eval-zl/claude-code/issues/54 (with all 26 labels applied)
- **PR #55**: https://github.com/mcpmark-eval-zl/claude-code/pull/55 (ready for review)
- **Documentation**: Complete label guide in `docs/LABEL_COLORS.md`

All requirements have been fulfilled, including the proper use of keywords, linking patterns, and comprehensive documentation of the repository's label system.
